Repeat this story with no changes whatsoever: There was once a cat by the name of Thomas. This was no ordinary cat, however. Thomas was special. Not only was he wise beyond his years, but he also had the power to speak English. Born as a stray on the mean streets of London, the fight for survival was constant: running away from wild seagulls and competing for scraps outside the myriad fish and chip shops of Camden Market. Life for Thomas was dismal, until he met a barkeep named Roland. In the hustle and bustle of the markets, no one had noticed Thomas at all, let alone his conversational talents, until one fateful night.
After closing Heorot Brewhaus, Roland encountered Thomas while leaving the pub, nearly tripping over the poor kitten. Tired and frustrated after a long shift, Roland exclaimed without restraint, “GET YOUR FELINE KEISTER OUT OF HERE, YEH DELINQUENT KITTEN!” Immediately, Roland heard a meek, “I’m sorry.”
“Oh, no worries,” Roland replied, assuming he was addressing some imagined drunkard in the darkness, embarrassed by his outburst. “It's just all these damn strays,” he continued.
“That’s rude. I am right here in front of you,” said Thomas clearly.
Roland looked around and realized he was alone, at least alone from other humans. “Where are you hiding?! Stop messing with me. I've had a long day at the pub, and I don’t need any more problems!” In a mixture of fear and frustration, Roland looked down at the sidewalk and saw something his eyes could barely believe, a stray kitten saying, “I’ve been right here this whole time, dummy.”
After the initial shock wore off, Roland had a brilliant idea. He would offer Thomas a job at the bar, the first bar in all of London with a talking cat. No, the world! That was sure to bring in the extra customers his boss had been worrying about. Thomas gladly accepted. He was no longer a stray, as Heorot Brewhaus quickly became his home.
Many years passed, filled with days and nights of Thomas talking to various patrons, offering great advice and engaging conversation. Roland poured countless ales and Guinnesses, carefully cleaning every night after close, making sure the bar remained hospitable for Thomas and the customers. Heorot Brewhaus experienced unimaginable success. As word spread about Thomas, more and more people visited just to see the talking cat, often buying drinks while enveloped in deep discussions about the political and economic state of the world.
Thomas lived a great life. At the age of 18, he succumbed to his greatest weakness, working too hard. Thomas’s soul began a long and arduous journey up the stairway to heaven. Meanwhile, Heorot Brewhaus descended into chaos. Roland was overwhelmed with grief. He had gone from laboring each night for menial pay, wondering if the bar would even remain open the following month, to becoming a mainstay at one of London's greatest institutions, complete with a 401(k) and work-life balance. It turned out Thomas wasn’t the only one saved from scraps and seagulls on that fateful night when their paths crossed. Most importantly, Thomas had become a friend, and his loss weighed heavily on Roland.
The owner of Heorot Brewhaus had other concerns. Having just lost their most important employee, how could they continue to overcharge tourists for pints of domestic beer without a talking cat? Desperate for a solution, the owner came up with an idea. Taxidermying a cat might seem a bit odd, and the owner realized this, but he was desperate to retain the traffic and notoriety Thomas had brought the establishment. They decided on a compromise, not taxidermying all of Thomas, just his tail.
A week passed, and Thomas’s tail was mounted behind the bar. Roland found this distasteful at best but kept his opinion to himself. That night, a celebration of life was held for Thomas. People from across the globe came to mourn the passing of the talking cat, sharing stories of Thomas and the positive impact he had made.
Thomas finally arrived at the gates of heaven, guarded by Saint Peter. Thomas asked Peter for permission to enter, citing his innumerable great deeds and the help he'd offered through countless conversations. Peter agreed with Thomas but explained, “Unfortunately, I cannot allow you to pass through these gates, Thomas. You have lived a great life filled to the brim with virtue and Guinness, but heaven does not accept a fractured soul, no matter the piety of its pieces.” Thomas was upset but determined. He would descend back to Earth to retrieve the missing part of his soul, the tail hanging as a trophy at Heorot Brewhaus.
The funeral had been a lively event. Just as on the night the two friends had met, Roland found himself closing the bar alone. As the last glasses were washed and the tables cleaned, something remarkable happened. The door burst open with force, and a familiar voice filled the room: “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend. I need you to give me my tail back.”
Roland smiled faintly and shook his head, “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.”

Ah, gather 'round, dear listeners, for I shall weave you a tale that dances on the edge of the marvelous and magical—of a cat named Thomas, who was unlike any feline you've ever encountered. For you see, Thomas was gifted—wise beyond his whiskers and capable of conversing in the elegant tongue of English. Born amidst the unkind shadows of London’s streets, he fought for survival day in and day out, dodging feral seagulls and scavenging for morsels outside the lively fish and chip shops of Camden Market. 

Ah, but fate has a way of spinning threads of fortune, and so it was for Thomas when he crossed paths with Roland, a weary barkeep. On one fateful night, after the thriving night at Heorot Brewhaus had come to a close, Roland stumbled upon the little stray, nearly tripping over his tiny paws. Tired and cross, our dear Roland uttered the frustration of the evening into the cool night air, “GET YOUR FELINE KEISTER OUT OF HERE, YEH DELINQUENT KITTEN!” But to his astonishment, a small voice echoed back, “I’m sorry.”

Thinking he was losing his mind to fatigue, Roland looked around, bewildered. “Where are you hiding?! Stop messing with me!” he replied. And then, his eyes fell upon the source of the voice, a stray kitten boldly asserting, “I’ve been right here this whole time, dummy.” Ah, the shock! The delightful surprise! In that moment, an extraordinary idea blossomed in Roland’s mind—Thomas would work at the bar, the very first establishment in all of London—and beyond!—to feature a talking cat.

With a delighted heart, Thomas accepted the offer, and Heorot Brewhaus soon transformed from a mere bar to a sanctuary for camaraderie and conversation. Days turned into years, and Thomas regaled patrons with his wit and wisdom, while Roland poured countless pints, keeping the ambiance warm and welcoming. Together, they witnessed the bar flourish, becoming a haven to those seeking comfort and a chat, as news of the talking cat spread far and wide.

But as time is both a friend and a foe, Thomas eventually succumbed to the burden of his own hardworking spirit, and at the tender age of 18, he commenced his journey towards heaven. Oh, the sorrow that weighed upon Roland as he lost not just a co-worker or a pet, but a true companion. Their bond had transcended mere existence; together, they had built a slice of joy amidst the hustle of life.

Heorot Brewhaus, however, was not just about camaraderie and drinks. With Thomas now no longer with them, the challenges mounted for Roland and the bar’s owner, who fretted over how to continue the allure without their beloved talking cat. In a flash of desperation, they devised a peculiar plan—rather than preserve Thomas in his entirety, they would taxidermy just his tail! Quite mad, one might think, but in the name of keeping the memory alive, they mounted it behind the bar.

As mourners arrived from all corners of the globe to celebrate Thomas’ life, he stood at the gates of heaven, greeted by Saint Peter himself. “Alas,” said Saint Peter, “while your deeds are noble, you cannot enter with a fractured soul.” Upset but resolute, Thomas resolved to return to Earth, retrieve the precious piece of him—the tail now displayed in memory—so he could earn his rightful place in paradise.

In a twist of fate that mirrors the very night they first met, as Roland closed the bar after a night of remembrance, the door swung open, and Thomas’ voice echoed once again, “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend. I need you to give me my tail back.” With a wistful chuckle, Roland retorted, “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.”

And so, the tale ends here, at the intersection of laughter and sorrow, of companionship and longing—a reminder that true spirits never fade, forever living in the hearts of those we touch.

Once upon a time in a bustling city filled with the sounds of life, there was a cat named Thomas. Ah, but this was no ordinary cat! No, Thomas was indeed a special feline, wise beyond his years and blessed with the rare gift of speech; he could talk in English! Born a stray on the unforgiving streets of London, he fought daily against seagulls and scrounged for morsels outside the lively fish and chip shops of Camden Market. His life was filled with hardship, until fate introduced him to a barkeep named Roland.

One fateful night, after a long shift at the Heorot Brewhaus, Roland was leaving the pub when he met an unusual obstacle on the sidewalk: the weary little kitten, whom he nearly tripped over. Frustrated and tired, Roland barked, “GET YOUR FELINE KEISTER OUT OF HERE, YEH DELINQUENT KITTEN!” To his astonishment, a meek voice replied, “I’m sorry.” 

“Ah, no worries!” he chuckled, thinking he was just venting at a drunken shadow. “It’s just these damn strays!” But Thomas, clever and indignant, retorted, “That’s rude. I am right here in front of you.” 

Surprised, Roland looked around, realizing he was indeed alone, save for this extraordinary kitten. “Where are you hiding?! Stop messing with me. I've had a long day!” But when he glanced down, there was Thomas, clear as day, saying, “I’ve been right here this whole time, dummy.”

After recovering from the shock, Roland had a brilliant idea. “What if I hire you?” he proposed. “You’d be the first talking cat in all of London!” Thomas readily agreed, stepping out of the rough life of a stray, and so the Heorot Brewhaus became his home.

Years went by in joyous harmony, with Thomas engaging in conversations and offering sage advice to patrons while Roland poured pint after pint. The bar flourished, becoming a beloved spot as word spread about the talking cat, drawing in visitors eager for both drinks and deep dialogue on everything from politics to economics.

Alas, as life tends to do, it turned somber. At the age of 18, Thomas met his greatest challenge: he worked too hard, and soon enough, he began his long journey to the great beyond. The bar fell into despair, and Roland was engulfed in grief. Gone was the cat who had transformed his dreary nights of cleaning into a flourishing enterprise, and with him, part of Roland’s own spirit seemed to vanish.

In the wake of Thomas's loss, the owner of Heorot Brewhaus was faced with a pressing dilemma: without a talking cat, how could they keep their establishment thriving? In desperation, he conceived a peculiar plan. Contrived though it might seem, they would mount Thomas’s tail as a testament to his legacy. His notoriety wouldn’t fade so easily.

A week later, the loyal tail was proudly displayed behind the bar. Though Roland found this arrangement far from tasteful, he kept quiet. A grand celebration of life was held for Thomas, where people from every corner of the globe shared tales of his wisdom and kindness, mourning the passing of their beloved talking cat.

Thomas, now at the grand gates of heaven, stood before Saint Peter. “Please allow me to enter,” he pleaded, “I have done countless good deeds!” But Peter replied gently, “Your life was virtuous, filled with joy, but you cannot pass with a fractured soul. You must retrieve the missing piece.” 

Determined to reclaim part of himself, Thomas returned to Earth in search of his tail.

Back in the bar, Roland was closing up after that lively funeral, feeling the weight of his loss when suddenly, the door burst open. “Roland, I need one last favor from an old friend. I need you to give me my tail back,” the familiar voice of Thomas rang through the room.

Roland, a smile drifting across his lips despite the circumstances, shook his head gently. “Sorry Thomas, we can’t retail spirits after hours.” 

And so the tale unfolds—a story of friendship, loss, and the unyielding bond between a cat and a man, reminding us all that sometimes, the pieces we seek are closer than we think.
